_comment: Interest Rate Spike Scenario - Refinancing Risk
_description: This case models a scenario where the initial mortgage is at 1.3% for the first 5 years, but then requires refinancing at year 6 with a much higher rate of 3.5% for the remaining 10 years. This tests the impact of interest rate risk and refinancing exposure.

_case_metadata.description: 1.3% initial rate, refinances to 3.5% at year 6. Tests refinancing risk.

financing._explanation: Initial financing terms are the same as base case. The interest rate spike occurs at refinancing (year 6).
financing._interest_rate_explanation: Initial interest rate of 1.3% for years 1-5. This will increase to 3.5% after refinancing at year 6.

rental._explanation: Rental assumptions remain the same as base case - no changes to occupancy or rates.

seasonal._explanation: Seasonal assumptions remain the same as base case.

expenses._explanation: Expense assumptions remain the same as base case.

projection._explanation: Projection assumptions with refinancing configuration. The interest rate will spike from 1.3% to 3.5% at year 6.

refinancing._explanation: Refinancing occurs at the start of year 6 (after 5 years). The new interest rate is 3.5%, representing a significant increase due to market conditions or credit reassessment.
refinancing._refinance_year_explanation: Refinancing happens at the start of year 6, meaning years 1-5 use the initial rate (1.3%), and years 6-15 use the new rate (3.5%).
refinancing._new_interest_rate_explanation: 3.5% interest rate after refinancing. This represents a 2.2 percentage point increase, which could occur due to: rising market rates, credit reassessment, or lender policy changes. This significantly impacts cash flow in years 6-15.
